Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on a video that was not taken in June 2019 but in July 2018.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the video of people chanting "We Love Trump" in the UK represents a large crowd of Trump supporters, which may not be accurate.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that news outlets reported larger protests against Trump during his visit to the UK in June 2019.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim can have an alternative explanation that the crowd seen in the video was actually a mixture of Trump fans and supporters of Tommy Robinson, rather than solely Trump supporters.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the significance and size of the crowd chanting "We Love Trump" by presenting it as a large crowd of Trump supporters when it may not be the case.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating bias in the claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting misleading images and videos on social media about pro- and anti-Trump crowds, which further complicates the issue and misrepresents the true nature of the events.
